all the way back in 1978 or something like that where it talks about how you
write code and how you write software and some princi principles around that and I think the if I recall correctly
like the the four or five principles there was that you know in order to make modular software number one is you make
each program do one thing really well so everything has one job and one job only
uh I think number two was uh you know there's like an an an output input exchange so like every program should
become the every every output of every program should become the input to another so if you've ever used Unix or
Linux and you pipe operations between command you're very familiar with those kind of approaches it's very again this
is from 1978 so very early days of computing um but the things that I I find most valuable especially in the
context of software as as a social practice that we all do the tools and the way you build your tools and
products uh and all these principles should be tailored to make sure that you lighten the programming task to other
maintainers uh and the idea that you know everything should be easily maintained and repurposed by developers
other than the people who created it so we would not be successful in the software industry if the person who
wrote the code the first time is the only person who's going to be able to maintain it forever that's why we have documentation that we have practices we
have guidelines of how to actually make software repurposable and sharable by others and that's why we have patterns
like forking and cloning and and sharing and sharing code because the whole point of all of this is that at the end of the
day software is about people and you want to make it so that you know some of these practices around mod poity is so
you know make it so that it's easy for others to come and repurpose or refactor or use your software without having to
go through you know TOS of manuals and understanding all your individual authors kind of purpose and and
knowledge and I think one other one that you know we all suffer from every day is you know one of the principles of the
Unix philosophy was everything should be designed in a way that you can just throw it away and rebuild it right and
as you know like in a in a monolithic world viw that's not such an easy thing to do but as you become as you focus on
building smaller and smaller units of code and build them in a modular fashion that is everything does one thing very
well every part of the program becomes an input to another you know everything can be rebuilt and thrown away and most
importantly it's built in a way that others can just come in understand it do
any changes or fixes and and move away without having to spend years and sync up with the original author and
everything so like to me those are kind of the key philosophy areas where like the again the philosophy kind of did
this very well back in 1978 um but in today's world we haven't really matured
